ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Independent Study
In addition to lecture videos, peer discussions were used to promote learning in this course (i.e., feedback on thesis).
I met with my advisor regularly throughout the semester.
Option to attend virtual lecture live
Independent research
This course was mostly self-led. We were responsible for meeting regularly with our advisors, meeting with our peer groups, and watching the recorded (or live) econometrics concepts workshops.
None.
recorded lecture
N/A
Virtual one on one meetings with advisor and office hours with instructors and a recorded lecture
Lectures were also recorded for future watching as well.
Live and recorded lecturers from Rebecca Toseland. Work with Thesis Advisor. Thesis study groups.
Occasional in-person baked good delivery

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about how to effective organize and conduct research.
Learn to perform independent research, apply economic/econometric/statistical knowledge to a real world application and work closely with data. Learn to write an academic research paper.
Even though I already had research experience going into the course, I've learned about a lot of the intricacies that go into conducting a research project from start to finish.
I have learned a ton about forming an original research topic, gathering data sets, cleaning them (oh jeez), coding, structuring and fitting regression models, and managing a huge project by oneself.
organizing for economics research, methods for causal inference, etc.
Econometrics techniques and data analysis, planning and organizing a research project, writing strategies
I learned more about several research strategies and techniques while also making progress on my economics senior essay.

That research is a challenging task. I'm sure everyone will come-up with something for which they'll be proud, but the road there is bumpy, or at least it has been for me. Econometrics is an important skill/knowledge that one should review.
I learned much of what I need to know in order to complete a Senior Thesis (research skills, R, writing, seeking advisors, choosing a topic, etc.).
Currently learning a ton about R because I chose a topic that requires a lot of it. Good skill to have!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the self-driven nature of the thesis as well as the immense support from my advisor compose the major strengths. My major challenge was acquiring data, but I feel that challenge is to be epected.
My thesis adviser is the best part of my project. It would be helpful to add econometric TAs/mentors to the class to help with the day-to-day research and code issues.

The concepts workshops would be more useful for me if they weren't all in R... I wish some of them were in STATA. Besides that, this course is what you make of it - the resources are definitely there for you if you seek them out!

Professor Toseland is great.  Though I wasn't able to attend any of her lectures in person, she is a great lecturer and the materials/tutorials she provides are extremely helpful.  The peer groups were also a joy!  There are no real weaknesses.
the course itself plays second fiddle to the senior essay that we work on separately (which is fine). I appreciate that the course gives some structure to and advice for the senior essay process.
No weakness really; it's about you putting in work and using your Advisor.
I appreciate the support this course offers. Writing a Senior Thesis is a tough task and I appreciate all the help available for me.
This course is what you make of it, so any strengths and weaknesses are on you.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the virtual meetings were effective.
More structure for meeting with professors since in-person is not allowed.
Overall, this course translates really well to online learning.
None.
I mean, everything was virtual. So it's fine.

I enjoyed the recorded lecture component of the course, as it enabled me to watch and rewatch the lectures at a time most convenient for me. The creation of virtual classmate groups was an effective way of sharing ideas as well.

Research is a very collaborative endeavor; I definitely wish that I could have just gone to my Advisor's office hours whenever I want in a normal year to discuss the project. There is nothing virtual that can replace that. It's been OK; I just have to set-up meetings with my Advisor. So this year, I think the experience is more individualistic for the student that usually, but I suppose that's a nice taste of Graduate School...
I appreciated the live research methods lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's almost entirely independent and very little work for the first semester. Definitely do a 2 term essay you'll get 2 credits for effectively 1 credit worth of work.
A thesis is an incredible opportunity to end your time at Yale.
Yes, do research and spend a whole year on a topic you care about!
Yes, I would recommend writing a senior essay if you want to try out independent research!
Absolutely.  Writing a thesis is fun, and the research/time-management skills you acquire are priceless!
to write the senior essay, I would recommend this course. It is effectively a placeholder for your credits, and allows you to work on the essay at your own pace.

I would recommend it if you're interested in writing an Econ senior essay, as it gives you the space to begin the writing process while also offering additional insight on the research techniques you might be using.

Yes, it's probably cool to go for Distinction if you want; I hope the thesis will be a nice project for me to remember about my Yale education. I think I am a little bit behind pace, but I'm not regretting that yet. It's nice to have a course in which you can do whatever you want, whenever you want. This is a course where it's not about showing your TA on a test that you know some material; it's about showing that to yourself.
It isn't always easy, but working on a Senior Essay is a nice capstone to the Yale experience. It also is a nice way to see if you might enjoy working on a PhD in Economics.
Do it if you want distinction in the major or are very excited to do your own project.
